author: afscrome

nodes.author: danegsta
danegsta
nodes.body: Seems like we should be able to package this up pretty easily into an advanced version of the WithVolume API that can accept the same owner, group, and umask arguments that WithContainerFiles takes.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: Only real downside to this is that the same container and volume configuration wouldn't necessarily behave the same outside of Aspire as most publish targets won't support this particular approach.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: Thinking about this some more, there's a real risk that in solving this with too much magic for the development scenario, we set users up for unexpected frustration when they try to run their image in production and find that volume permissions suddenly don't work as they did locally.

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
> Thinking about this some more, there's a real risk that in solving this with too much magic for the development scenario, we set users up for unexpected frustration when they try to run their image in production and find that volume permissions suddenly don't work as they did locally.

There is a risk with that, but volume permissions have enough quirks based on your deployment target / cloud provider that without this magic, reality is that you hit separate permission problems in dev vs your deployment target.  So you could view this as eliminating one of two pain points, rather than moving a pain point from local dev to production.

I wonder if we need some higher level filesystem type abstractions?

We now have a few different ways of getting files into containers (bind mounts, volumes, ).  Each of which has their own quirks, and the quirks also vary based on the environment you deploy to (docker vs compose vs k8s).  I suspect he majority of people don't really care how we get the files into a container, just that they're there.  The generic api could also help mitigate some of the magic concerns as you'd expect a bit more magic from a higher level api, and those who dont' want that magic can fall back to the specific implementations.

This abstraction could also apply to non container resources (e.g. using `IAspireStore` for executable / project resources).  And in turn this abstraction would help with #8984, allowing you to specify files / directories in a way that applies to both container, project and executables (and more).

My initial thought for this was something like `.WithFile()`, `.WithDirectory()`, where inputs include File/Directory name,' permissions, initial contents

But then I feel like you'll want to reference these files programmatically (particularly with #8984 in mind where you don't know the TargetPath and will need a `ReferenceExpression` type thing, so maybe they need to be dedicated sub-resources.

```cs
var sqlLite = app.AddFile()
app.WithEnvironment("SQLITE_DB, sqlLite)
```

(Don't think these are final API shapes, just a few minutes of throwing initial ideas out from me)

title: Make writeable Volumes work for non root users

author: alexandrektgomes
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Hi,

I'm encountering an issue after upgrading from Aspire 8.2.2 to Aspire 9.2.1. In version 8.2.2, I was able to create a Docker container (specifically for [mountebank](https://www.mbtest.org/)) with multiple exposed ports using Aspire. However, after migrating to 9.2.1, the same configuration fails to start the container.

Sample Code: `  var builder = DistributedApplication.CreateBuilder(args);

        builder.AddContainer("mountebank", "bbyars/mountebank")
            .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 5000, targetPort: 5000, name: StorageSharedService)
            .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 9000, targetPort: 9090, name: "control");

        await builder.Build().RunAsync().ConfigureAwait(true);`

Error: `Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ContainerReconciler[0]
could not create the container {"Container": {"name":"mountebank-qqtkwshe"}, "Reconciliation": 3, "ContainerName": "mountebank-qqtkwshe", "error": "object not found\ncontainer not found\ndocker command 'CreateContainer' returned with non-zero exit code 1: command output: Stdout: '' Stderr: ''"}`

### Expected Behavior

Aspire should allow the creation of a Docker container with multiple exposed ports, as it did in 8.2.2.



### Steps To Reproduce

1. Use Aspire 9.2.1.
3. Define a container resource with multiple ports exposed (e.g., 2525, 4545).
5. Run the app and observe container creation failure.

### Exceptions (if any)

`Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ContainerReconciler[0]
      could not create the container    {"Container": {"name":"mountebank-jevkhtef"}, "Reconciliation": 3, "ContainerName": "mountebank-jevkhtef", "error": "object not found\ncontainer not found\ndocker command 'CreateContainer' returned with non-zero exit code 1: command output: Stdout: '' Stderr: ''"}`

### .NET Version info

.NET 8

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
@alexandrektgomes we have unit tests that verify containers with multiple exposed ports and I haven't seen other reports of issues related to the number of ports exposed nor been able to reproduce myself. Often, that specific error can indicate the Docker runtime itself is unhealthy (the docker command to create the container returned a -1 exit code).

A good way to troubleshoot if something is wrong with Docker is to try to run a similar command from a terminal and see if it succeeds or fails. This should be the equivalent command for the example container and error you provided (Aspire also creates a network to connect the container, but we only need to worry whether that's part of the problem if this command succeeds):

```bash
docker container create --name mountebank-abcdefg -p 127.0.0.1:5000:5000 -p 127.0.0.1:9000:9090 bbyars/mountebank:latest
```

If that command succeeds it should output the ID of a new container that's in a `created` state (we create and start the container in two separate commands instead of a single `run` command). In the event that running that command fails, the next step is likely to restart your Docker runtime (or your whole machine) to see if the problem resolves on its own.

If the command ends up succeeding when run from the terminal, I can walk you through enabling debug logging for the orchestrator which can provide more details about the specific Docker command being run.

nodes.author: alexandrektgomes
nodes.body:
Hey @danegsta  thanks for the help!

The command runs successfully and returns the container ID of the created container, which is able to run. I restarted both the Docker runtime and the computer, but Aspire continues to show the same error. I also tested it on a coworker's computer, and he encountered the same issue.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
@alexandrektgomes what OS are you running on and how do you have Docker installed (Docker Desktop, manual Docker daemon install, etc.)? And do you know what version of Docker you have installed (running `docker version` should give you client and server versions). Asking just in case there's a particular environment we're not considering in our tests/validation.

Also, if you check Docker while your app host is running, do you see a container added in a created state (not running yet)? If you're listing containers from the command line, you may need to pass the `-a` flag to include all containers. I'm wondering if we failed to create the container or failed to inspect the container.

Running the app host with orchestrator logging enabled may reveal some additional information about what exactly is failing. If you set the `DCP_DIAGNOSTICS_LOG_LEVEL` environment variable to `debug`, the orchestrator will write detailed logs to disk. By default it'll write logs to `$TEMP/dcp/logs` (where `$TEMP`) is your standard temp folder. You can override that output path by setting the `DCP_DIAGNOSTICS_LOG_FOLDER` environment variable to the folder path you'd like us to write the logs to.

If you run your project and reproduce the error with those environment variables set, you'll see a number of log files get written; the one that'll be the most interesting will have `dcpctrl` in the name as that's the actual orchestration logs (you may have multiple log files with `dcpctrl` in them if you run your project multiple times with logging enabled; the log files have the timestamp they were created as part of their name, so they should be in order by time created by default).

Once you've reproduced the error with logging enabled, you'll want to try to find the `could not create the container` error in your `dcpctrl` log file. There should be additional diagnostic logging around there indicating what command was run (and what the output and error code was). Look for a log entry with a `docker create` command as that should give you the exact command we ran to create the container (as well as the ID of the container if we think it was created successfully). That create command log entry (or others between it and the error) may help indicate what's actually going wrong. Just be careful to check any entries you share from those detailed logs for personal information before posting them.

nodes.author: alexandrektgomes
nodes.body:
Hey @danegsta,

I think it is related to the fact that I'm running the application on Windows, but the containers are being created on WSL.

title: Error when exposing multiple ports on Docker container

author: ChristopherRWilson
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

On one specific computer, I am unable to run any Aspire project. If I try to run it with the standard template, it looks like it is running but the server will not respond. If I include a reference to a postgres database, the console throws a Polly Timeout exception while loading and the application stops.

The computer that this won't run on is connected to a domain, and has the Cisco Secure Client with Secure Endpoint and Umbrella activated. The issue happens when both connected directly to the corporate network, when connected via VPN, and when not connected to the corporate network but logged in using a domain account. I don't see any relevant logs in the Cisco client's logs.

I suspect this issue is either a misconfiguration on the laptop or related to the Cisco client, but I am unable to find any relevant logs pointing to the root cause.

This is a continuation of a question posted to reddit on /r/dotnet and was requested to continue the troubleshooting here. https://www.reddit.com/r/dotnet/comments/1kob27m/cant_get_aspire_with_postgres_to_run_on_one/

Tagging the people I was talking with on reddit, as well as another that I was requested to tag the github issue with.
@karolz-ms @maddymontaquila @davidfowl 

Thank you!

### Expected Behavior

Aspire application should load the dashboard when navigating to the URL supplied in the terminal

### Steps To Reproduce

Clone https://github.com/ChristopherRWilson/AspireWontLoad

Attempt to run the AspireWontLoad.AppHost project

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: Setting the `DCP_DIAGNOSTICS_LOG_LEVEL` environment variable to `debug` will enable diagnostic logging for DCP to `%TEMP%\dcp\logs`. You’ll see a log entry for each process run, but the interesting ones are going to be the `dcp` and `dcpctrl` logs (most likely the`dcpctrl` logs will be the most insightful).

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
That particular log line is just a bit of noise from our runtime checker (it should probably be "debug" instead of "info" level). We check at runtime to see if "Podman" or "Docker" is installed (preferring Docker if both are found). That particular log entry is just that container runtime check reporting that we didn't find Podman on the system.

I think any useful info is going to be in the `dcpctrl` logs as nothing looks out of the ordinary in the `dcp` logs. `dcpctrl` is responsible for the actual orchestration (launching processes, creating containers, running service proxies, etc.) while `dcp` just holds the model and doesn't do much active logging except at startup and shutdown.

nodes.author: ChristopherRWilson

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
`dcpctrl` and `dcp` both use the same logging configuration (the `DCP_DIAGNOSTICS_LOG_LEVEL` environment variable above). It's quite possible the underlying issue is that something is preventing `dcpctrl` from running (at least long enough that the startup readiness check times out).

You can try manually running `dcp` outside of Aspire to see if `dcpctrl` is able to launch eventually given enough time.

Based on the paths in your logs, running the following line will launch DCP standalone with verbose logging to the terminal:
`C:\\TFS\\nuget\\.nuget\\packages\\aspire.hosting.orchestration.win-x64\\9.2.1\\tools\\dcp.exe start-apiserver -v=1`

You should eventually see `dcpctrl` tagged log entries from the output (and see a dcpctrl process running) if everything is working correctly. Ctrl+c will shut down the individual processes.

nodes.author: ChristopherRWilson
nodes.body:
Finally figured it out, thanks to issue #10268. I have a dev drive mounted as both my D: drive, as well as a symlink folder mounted at C:\TFS\. I changed all environment variables, including `NUGET_PACKAGES` from pointing to the C:\TFS\ symlink to the mounted drive at D:, rebooted, and now everything works.

I'm not sure if this is the same issue as #10268 or not, because I was never getting the error message that they are reporting. It seemed similar enough that I went ahead and tried their fix though.

title: Aspire will not run on corporate computer

author: pomianowski
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

I have an stack built with:
 - Some persistent database container, like PostgreSQL
 - Some persistent queue container, like RabbitMQ
 - Another team's container
 - Another team's container migrating the database (one-time cli app)
 - My application
 etc...

After updating to Aspire 9.3 (https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/8477), the CLI application displays **Exited** upon completion, what is great.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/2c5ec1b0-7d85-4067-bd27-c30f2dc8b7dc)

But when I mark CLI lifetime as persistent, anyway every time I start the AppHost, the cli in container starts again.

I have a suggestion that if I have consciously marked these applications as persistent, and Aspire knows that they correctly Exited with code 0, then do not restart them on the next attempt.

### Describe the solution you'd like

If a container has gracefully exited and has been marked persistent, do not restart it when restarting AppHost.

### Additional context

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/4366
https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/6785

https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/pull/8477

nodes.author: HighFiveYeah
nodes.body: Would be great to have that onboard. Seems very intuitive.

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Overloading `ContainerLifetime.Persistent` for this feels very counter intuitive for me as you asking for the complete opposite of persistence - `continuing to exist or occur over a prolonged period.`  But what you want here is the complete opposite - a container that lives for a very short time, and then never runs again.  This to me feels like it should be a different lifetime e.g. `ContainerLifetime.RunOnce`.  Or perhaps a `.WithRunOnce()` on the container along the lines of `.WithExplicitStart()`.

If Aspire were to do something special with persistent containers when they exit, I'd more expect aspire to auto re-start the service to ensure it's running.  (Although even in this use case, I'd prefer a `.WithRestartOnExit()` method rather than overloading `ContainerLifetime.Persistent`)

title: Don't restart container if exit code was `0` and `WithLifetime` is set to persistent

author: davidfowl
body:
Any errors that come from dcp or the apphost itself don't show up when using aspire run. This makes it really hard to diagnose problems (we hit this on the live stream with port conflicts).

Generally, we need a first-class way to capture logs from the app host without parsing the console output.  I think that means a custom logger provider that writes logs to the back channel in a structured way so that the cli can build custom rendering on top.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
I agree we need to do something (I watched the video where you guys tackled Bitwarden). It should be straight forward to pull logs across the back channel for the apphost.


The real question is one of visual presentation.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Other thought was we add the app host to the dashboard itself, e.g. as a pseudo resource. That way you could see its console logs and if we hooked up OTel to it could get all that goodness too.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: New approach #9990

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: Note that this is an issue in the non-CLI scenarios too, e.g. when launched from VS. The dashboard is popped open in a browser and folks don't know to look in the popped terminal to see AppHost logs.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body: So we've merged in the change to the CLI so it now outputs a link to the logs so that if there are DCP errors etc it will be available there. Do we want to try and make the AppHost show up as a resource in 9.4?

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body:
>Do we want to try and make the AppHost show up as a resource in 9.4?

I think we need to try and do something, yeah. Do we have consensus on the approach of the AppHost being a pseudo-resource?

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: No, I think @danegsta updated DCP to make it so that we can discovery what logs are for which resource? If so, we can route errors to the console using the resource logger.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
nodes.body:
I think provided we can launch he dashboard that gives us what we want (routing DCP errors to the resource via the resource logger).

Far easier than trying to parse it out of a single log anyway.

If the dashboard fails to launch then the app host logs will show that pretty clearly.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body:
> Far easier than trying to parse it out of a single log anyway.

We already parse it them. This is about pushing resource specific DCP errors to the per resource logs as well.

nodes.author: mitchdenny
mitchdenny
nodes.body: I've been looking at this. I think we'll need to punt the routing of DCP reconciler errors to the resource logger, we'll need to come up with a better way of identifying which log line is associated with a resource (if any). It'll probably need to be a DCP side change followed by some tweaks to the parsing logic in `GetLogInfo(...)`.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
We have an issue about this on the DCP side https://github.com/microsoft/usvc/issues/219 the idea being that you can ask for "all DCP logs (errors and warnings) that are relevant for specific resource". This would come as a separate log stream, but you could combine it with the regular logs from the resource in the CLI/dashboard.

I do not think trying to parse all DCP logs yourself will set you up for success. They contain a lot of internal diagnostics stuff and we make zero guarantees about them being the same from release to release.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @danegsta punt to next version?

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
> [@danegsta](https://github.com/danegsta) punt to next version?

Yeah, we've got the new log sources in DCP, but need to figure out the best way to integrate them into the existing logging experience in the dashboard (and CLI).

title: Error logs output from the apphost and dcp don't show up during `aspire run`

author: JamesNK
body:
1. Public endpoint on a resource, anything can talk to it because it's a public endpoint.
2. Within the container network, containers can talk to each other because there is a container network.
3. Container to host network, via gateway.
4. Isolated network, that don't have gateway or external, no access.
5. Modeling how endpoints related to compute environments.

title: Aspire networking scenarios to validate

author: JamesNK
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

If a resource that has a proxy that DCP can't start because port is in use, DCP will incorrectly report that the resource is running. For example:

```cs
var s1Echo = builder
    .AddContainer("s1-echo", "hashicorp/http-echo")
    .WithHttpEndpoint(8080, targetPort: 5678);

s1Echo
    .WithEnvironment("ECHO_TEXT", $"Hello from {s1Echo.GetEndpoint("http")}");
```
If port 8080 is in use then DCP will report the resource is running and green in the dashboard. In the background it will retry for a long time to start the proxy on 8080. Trying to access the resource using 8080 will fail. This is confusing to the user because the resource reports it is running successfully.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e5be0f16-5fd3-4a71-9243-949dc81bc714)

DCP eventually it writes an error message to the app host console:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4de35d78-6541-417b-af03-0ceddf064d4d)

### Expected Behavior

The resource should be in a `Starting` state until the proxy at 8080 is running. If DCP can't run the proxy then the resource should go into a `FailedToStart` state. Right now there is a very long timeout when trying to start the proxy. I think 30 seconds is probably the max we should make users wait before giving them feedback.

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
The container is actually running fine. It is just that its endpoint cannot be proxied. So we need to figure out how we handle/report this. One possibility is to report that the container is running, but "unhealthy".

@DamianEdwards mentioned that the endpoint that did not get its target port should be considered "inactive" and hidden. So that is another possiblity.

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: I think ideally, in addition to status changes, the log messages indicating the port issue should go to the impacted resource logs, rather than to the app host logs

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @karolz-ms dcp has to make it easy for the apphost to correlate where these logs should end up (this is generally true of many errors like this).

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: We have feature for this in our backlog ("startup logs" for Executables). I will make a note of this scenario there.

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: Putting on the backlog for now but will try to fit this in soon but likely after 9.4

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body: This error could also be a bit more explicit about the endpoint it impacts - I now know enough about dcp to know that the `servicename` in the error is really `{ResourceName}-{EndpointName}` and so can derive the impacted endpoint, but that may not be obvious to new users.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: @dbreshears can we fix the log output so the apphost can push it into the right output?

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: Just to make sure we are all on the same page @davidfowl @DamianEdwards @JamesNK @afscrome : we want errors related to proxying/routing requests to container/executable instances to show in logs for *all affected instances*. This means that if there are multiple replicas of a container/executable, all instances will have a warning/error entry.

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: Yes

title: Resource proxy port conflict isn't reflected in resource dashboard

author: JohnGalt1717
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

On VS.net, and Rider especially but also VS Code periodically, one or more of my projects (micro services) in the Aspire host will break on an error spinning up Kestrel and attaching to a port.  Occasionally the port that doesn't get released is the Aspire Dashboard itself.

There doesn't seem to be any rhyme nor reason to it. It isn't about stop then start right away or clicking restart, it just doesn't release the ports and you have to close the IDE entirely and then it will work again on reopen.  Very occasionally that doesn't work and you have to restart.

This happens on 3 separate Aspire projects that share only a little in common, and happens on Mac (VS Code and Rider) and Windows 11 Stable (all 3)

Once while using VS code, I looked in in the task manager and none of the dotnet processes had been killed. I killed them and restarted and it worked again.  In Vs.net I don't see similar but am wondering if it's named something else when debugging so I don't see it.

I generally just click the stop button in the IDE, I don't close the aspire dashboard or anything else.

Should regularly start without having to close the IDE and reopen.

1. Create a marginally complex Aspire Host with database, Local AI (ollama), and Redis.
2. Make sure you have 3 or 4 .net 9 projects running minimal apis that spin up and use these things.
3. Start the aspire dashboard for debugging.
4. Stop the session using the IDE Stop button.
5. Start a new session with the start button. (or hit restart)

nodes.author: JohnGalt1717
nodes.body: If it helps, I just got one that normally would have caused me to have to restart my computer. I found these still running after all instances of vs.net were closed and verified that devenv wasn't running: Killing them and then restarting vs.net fixed it and the aspire host ran with all projects just fine.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
Those particular processes are background workers run by VS that are used for a number of different purposes (some IDE synchronization with Aspire is managed through such a process, but nothing that would directly be running processes). When running Aspire in VS, service projects are launched by VS to allow the full debugging experience if necessary (even when doing a run without debugging). If you're running your application with debugging, VS should be aggressively terminating the AppHost and service projects as soon as debugging stops (VS notoriously doesn't allow for graceful process shutdown when debugging, it just terminates the whole process tree) which should immediately release the bound ports.

One thing to double check that has come up before is to make sure that you don't have your IDE configured to run multiple startup projects; if a service project is configured as a startup project along with the AppHost, you can end up with two copies trying to run at the same time which will definitely lead to port conflicts as they'll both try to bind to the same configured port.

nodes.author: JohnGalt1717
nodes.body: Double checked and it is only launching the AppHost.

nodes.author: JohnGalt1717
nodes.body:
FYI this is still happening with 9.4.0

It's really easy to see what's happening in Rider and VS Code as it is leaving dotnet instances in task manager.  Restarting vs code or rider clears these.

When it doesn't work after restart of the apps, there are dead versions (often dozens) that you have to manually kill and then restarting the apps fixes it.

VS.net is hidden more, but those processes I mention are still hung in the case were a restart of vs.net doesn't fix the issue.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: Can you try reproducing running Aspire directly from the command line instead of via IDE? There are some differences in how projects are launched when running in an IDE, so determining if it's specific to IDEs will help narrow down further avenues of inquiry.

nodes.author: JohnGalt1717
nodes.body:
Latest aspire cli 9.4.1:

filter task manager for "dotnet"

Nothing running.

aspire run

It starts up as normal.

Ctrl + c

Wait a while and task manager shows a .net host left around instead of being cleaned up.

It never goes away.

It also in 15 tries hasn't once locked ports.

I also noted that VS.net and Rider both have a orphan collector process running still when this happens.  Vs code just seems to leave around a locked .net process. Rider seems to leave around a locked and running .net process AND the collector.  Vs.net leaves around just the debug process and the collector.

nodes.author: JohnGalt1717
nodes.body:
I *think* I found the problem.

The libraries for aspire were upgraded but the SDK wasn't.

Some suggestions:

1. The notification on the dashboard should find this and report it.
2. the aspire cli needs an aspire upgrade and it should let you pick some or all of the aspire hosts in the solution (and default to all) and upgrade all libraries and sdks automatically.

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Continuation of #8206, but that issue has been locked.

If a containers crashes upon startup it still continues to report no logs in both 9.3 and 9.4.0-preview.1.25351.3.

9.4 does have some improvement in that it tells me the container crashed (all be it with a rather confusing error), but the logs are still missing.

```
    fail: Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.dcpctrl.ContainerReconciler[0]
      failed to start Container	{"Container": {"name":"REDCTED-mkvtbbkr"}, "Reconciliation": 39, "ContainerID": "aeecc55e407fb644a0fd24dda32536c7a52511566f67bd54da7c19d451d967dd", "error": "container 'REDACTED-mkvtbbkr' start failed (exit code 1)\nwriter is closed\nnot all requested objects were returned\nonly 0 out of 1 containers were successfully started"}
```

This issue is a significant blocker towards us using Distributed Application Testing builder - when (not if) we screw something up and cause the app to crash on startup, we're pretty much unable to debug.  Not only does DCP not report the logs, but it also immediately deletes the container from docker when it crashes, so you can't even pull the logs of the stopped container through docker.

The fix for our crash is almost certainly a silly missing environment variable, but lack of logs means we're unable to see exactly what we're missing.

### Expected Behavior

_No response_

### Steps To Reproduce

_No response_

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: afscrome
dbreshears
nodes.body: Could be that the DistributedApplicationTestingBuilder is not subscribing to the startup logs.   That needs to be investigated.

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: @afscrome , do you have a repro or way that we can simulate the crash

nodes.author: afscrome
afscrome
nodes.body:
Absolute simplest scenario would be something like

```cs
        appHost.AddContainer("nginx", "nginx") // or any base image of your choice with bash
            .WithEntrypoint("bash")
            .WithArgs("-c", "echo hello world; exit 123");
```

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
Also looks like it's not container specific - you can get similar behaviour with a short lived executable.  (Logs showing up in dashboard, but not in test output)

```cs
        appHost.AddExecutable("cmd", "cmd.exe", ".")
            .WithArgs("/c", "echo Hello World!");
```

author: taoyouh
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

If a dev drive was mounted as a folder and env variable `NUGET_PACKAGES` is set to somewhere inside the mounted dev drive, attempting to launch Aspire will fail saying "directory junctions are not supported, use directory symbolic link instead".

The issue was first submitted as #6114. That issue was marked completed but it only fixed symbolic links. Mounts still don't work.

### Expected Behavior

Aspire shall launch normally even if `NUGET_PACKAGES` are in a mounted-as-folder dev drive.

### Steps To Reproduce

1. (on Windows) Create a dev drive (see https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/dev-drive/#how-to-set-up-a-dev-drive) and mount the dev drive as a folder (for example E:\taoyouh\dev)
2. Set environment variable `NUGET_PACKAGES` to somewhere insided the mounted dev drive (for example E:\taoyouh\dev\.nuget\packages)
3. `cd` to an empty dir
4. Create a new Aspire app host project using command `dotnet new aspire-apphost`
5. Launch the project with command `dotnet run` and it will fail

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: Unfortunately,  directory junctions are not supported across drives so this is not supported.  You will need to use symbolic links.

nodes.author: taoyouh
nodes.body:
> Unfortunately, directory junctions are not supported across drives so this is not supported. You will need to use symbolic links.

Unsupported by what?

And, how can I use symbolic links when the drive is mounted as a folder? Mounting a drive as a folder is a valid use case and Aspire is just not working with it.

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body:
Aspire orchestrator.   Mounting the drive appears to create a junction which can be seen using "dir /al".   A couple of options/questions:   

Why not just create a folder on your DevDrive and set NUGET_PACKAGES environment variable to that location rather than mount the dev drive as a folder?

As another possibility, you can create a Symbolic link to a folder by executing this from an admin powershell terminal.

```
New-ITem -ItemType SymbolicLink -Path c:\Nuget -Target D:\
```

nodes.author: DamianEdwards
nodes.body: @dbreshears the scenario here is when a Dev Drive is mounted as a folder, which is supported scenario using the Windows Dev Drive setup experience. Moving the NuGet package location to the Dev Drive is then suggested by Dev Home, so people hitting this are simply using supported features of Windows 11. Can we investigate a further and determine exactly what the issue is here and why it only appears to impact Aspire and not NuGet in general?

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: @DamianEdwards , Investigated a bit.   It appears it would be a bit costly to implement and I believe the same effect can be achieved by using a symbolic link or the recommendations above.   I'll reopen but unsure when we can prioritize.

author: afscrome

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body: Probably in network cleanup, but lets do a detailed perf trace and see if we can make improvements on shutdown

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body: @afscrome this happens on Windows, correct?

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
The reason why I am asking is because on Windows we try to be nice and shut down Executables using `GenerateConsoleCtrlEvent` (sending CTRL+BREAK, in lieu of signals available on other OSes). For reasons that are not entirely clear to me it takes approximately 5 seconds for each Executable to get and process that event... with result that it takes about 6-7 seconds total to dispose of the app, and that time is dominated by Executable cleanup. Adding Containers makes no difference.

For comparison, on Linux I see the app disposal taking approximately 1.5 seconds for Executable-only version and about 2.5 seconds for version with Containers, which I think is reasonable.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
The other thing that I forgot to mention is that when `app.StartAsync()` returns, it does not mean everything is necessarily up and running. It only means the Aspire app model has created all the objects and got the information it needs to consider the application "started". For both Executables and Containers DCP might still be manipulating them, and it could be that some of these actions need to reach their outcome before cleanup can be started. E.g. this explains why a network created event shows up for some runs with your test--it is a timing issue. In my testing I actually added a delay after `app.StartAsync()` and measured shutdown time only after that, to make sure the shutdown starts from a stable state.

The cleanup itself is also a bit involved. E.g. for Containers we stop them gracefully, then verify they are really stopped, then remove them, then verify they are actually removed, then (after all ephemeral containers have been removed) delete the container network, then verify it is deleted. So that involves multiple round-trips to Docker/Podman and just takes time (and you do not want to know why we do all the verification 😄). Unlike with startup, we want to make 100% sure that the cleanup is done, all of it, before reporting the shutdown complete, because another instance of the same test might be started right after we report cleanup done, and if there are any resources still running at that time, conflicts may occur.

I looked at the detailed logs and, apart from the CTRL+BREAK issue on Windows, I did not see any evidence of clearly excessive time spent in any phase of the resource cleanup.

nodes.author: afscrome
nodes.body:
>  I forgot to mention is that when app.StartAsync() returns, it does not mean everything is necessarily up and running

I must admit, I still struggle to make sense of when `StartAsync` blocks and when it doesn't .  When you use `WaitFor(), `StartAsync` gets blocked by all of those dependencies starting.  But use `WithExplicitStart()` instead and that doesn't block.  

> we want to make 100% sure that the cleanup is done, all of it

What if I don't care, or the time saving is significant enough that I want to take the risk of some edge case failures?
- When I'm running tests in a test process, why can't the cleanup of the previous test overlap with the running of the next test?   I can already run tests in parallel, so I'd imagine that overlapped cleanup is no different to a slightly higher degree of parallelism.
- I'm running on an ephemeral build agent.  Once my test are complete, the agent is going to be completely erased.

Sure 5 seconds cleanup for a test may not be unreasonably, but multiply that by 100 tests and it becomes significant.  It also produces a really poor first impressin as devs will typically start with a hello world type test, and it is these test where the disposal is most obvious, leading to poor first impressions.

All of this is also made worse by `DistributedApplicationTestingBuilder` encouraging the model of one app host per test, rather than an assembly wide one time set up.  (Whilst technically you can do the latter, it makes it a nightmare to get logs out of so failures become undiagnosable.

nodes.author: karolz-ms
nodes.body:
> I must admit, I still struggle to make sense of when StartAsync blocks and when it doesn't . When you use WaitFor(), StartAsyncgets blocked by all of those dependencies starting.  But useWithExplicitStart()` instead and that doesn't block.

`WithExplicitStart()` implies the resource start is asynchronous and on-demand--it may be started at any time after creation, or not at all. The fact that `StartAsync()` does not block on such resources being started makes a lot of sense to me. @mitchdenny or @davidfowl might have more thoughts on that.

> What if I don't care, or the time saving is significant enough that I want to take the risk of some edge case failures?

There is `WaitForResourceCleanup` [option on DCP Publisher](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/src/Aspire.Hosting.Testing/DistributedApplicationFactory.cs#L204) that is on by default but you can turn it of [via extension method](https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/blob/main/tests/Shared/DistributedApplicationTestingBuilderExtensions.cs#L38). Please check it out and let me know if it helps!

> Sure 5 seconds cleanup for a test may not be unreasonably, but multiply that by 100 tests and it becomes significant. It also produces a really poor first impressin as devs will typically start with a hello world type test, and it is these test where the disposal is most obvious, leading to poor first impressions.

I think Aspire makes it almost too easy to spin up multi-service, multi-container environments for tests 😆 OK, I am joking a bit, but the costs of these things does add up. My advice would be to do more environment reuse for multiple test scenarios and/or rely more on testing services in isolation.

> All of this is also made worse by DistributedApplicationTestingBuilder encouraging the model of one app host per test, rather than an assembly wide one time set up. (Whilst technically you can do the latter, it makes it a nightmare to get logs out of so failures become undiagnosable.

I think this is a reasonable default and not just because of the log issue. If one throws diverse test scenarios at the same set of instances, there is an opportunity not only for failures related to individual scenarios, but also failures caused by scenario interaction. Which may or may not be symptoms of implementation defects, but surely make test specificity and robustness more challenging.

title: Disposing `DistributedApplicationTestingBuilder` takes longer than the test itself

author: Sjark
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

Both Docker build and podman build supports setting --ssh default to be able to forward an ssh key into the container during build. This can be used to do stuff like restore python dependencies from private github repos.

As far as I can tell, there is no option today to set the ssh flag when using AddDockerfile. 

### Describe the solution you'd like

I would either add an api like WithSshMount, or be able to set any build flag with something like WithDockerBuildArgs

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: Sjark
nodes.body:
A workaround for this is to manually run `docker build . --ssh=default` manually every time we have updated a dependency, so that the dependency step of the docker build is cached. Aspire run will the use the cached version of the docker image and not throw any access denied errors when building the docker images.

This is not ideal, but works fine until support for custom docker/podman are added.

title: Allow setting SSH flag when using containers

author: afscrome
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

We are sharing a bunch of internal integrations for containerised version of our apps.  As our app is continuously delivered, we pretty much always want internal users using the latest version of our images, there are few options we could use to do this

1. Reference the mutable tag (e.g. `latest` / `production` / `stable`)
2. Use `WithImagePullPolicy(ImagePullPolicy.Always)`
3. Use a fixed image tag / sha in our published component, and re-publish our integration package

However each of these has drawbacks

1. Referencing the `latest` tag will get you the `latest` container when you first run your app, but from then on it will keep on using the local version and won't ever update itself (unless someone explicitly re-pulls the image)
2. `WithImagePullPolicy(ImagePullPolicy.Always)` will causes docker to fail to start if it cannot pull the image for any reason (no network, credential expired etc.)
3. This only keeps the container up to date if consumers keep the nuget package up to date.  For continuously deployed apps, this could update the integration package several times a day which is a lot of updates - either manual or dependabot style prs).



### Describe the solution you'd like

Some kind of way that would allows us to try to get the up to date `latest` container, but allow falling back to a local one if you can't do so.

Something like the following would be awesome.
```cs
builder.AddContainer("redis", "redis")
    .WithImagePullPolicy(ImagePullPolicy.IfPossible)
```

Unfortunately, this won't be as simple as the existing pull policies - the current pull policies are somewhat standardized and are natively implemented in docker and kubernetes, so Aspire needs to do little more than pass an additional command line argument / yaml configuration

- https://kubernetes.io/docs/concepts/containers/images/#image-pull-policy
- https://docs.docker.com/reference/cli/docker/container/run/#pull

But `IfPossible` would require Aspire doing a bit more clever work - My initial thought would be implementing of https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/5625#issuecomment-2614797582 - having aspire handle the image pull separately from starting the container.  In which case `IfPossible` would initially try to pull the image but continue on error.  The container could then start if the image is already in the local cache, or fail if it wasn't.

For publish, `IfPossible`, would likely need to translate to `missing` / `IfNotPresent`, meaning `IfPossible` only applies locally.

### Additional context
title: Keeping referenced containers automatically up to date

author: ThatzOkay
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe the problem.

I am trying to add glutun as a container which require the capability NET_ADMIN. I could not find a way to add it.

### Describe the solution you'd like

Like a WithCapability("NET_ADMIN") which you can chain to add capabilities

### Additional context

_No response_

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: As a workaround in the short term, you can pass arbitrary arguments to the run command using the `WithContainerRuntimeArgs` API. So `.WithContainerRuntimeArgs("--add-cap", "NET_ADMIN")` should add that capacity to a container.

nodes.author: ThatzOkay
nodes.body: Thanks `.WithContainerRuntimeArgs("--cap-add", "NET_ADMIN")` works for now. Still would be better to have easy method to add it

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: Yeah, we’ll keep the issue open; just wanted to get you unblocked in the short term.

title: Ability to define Capabilities

nodes.author: dbreshears
nodes.body:
Going to add this to the backlog.   Actually turns out to not be as simple as checking if the length of the arguments exceeding the kubernetes metadata annotations limit as several other pieces contribute to the annotations and the length of all annotations coming from apphost can be several KB over 256 and still not repro,  so after investigating in both Apphost and DCP there doesn't seem to be a definitive way to handle and emit a warning / error.  I guess a warning could be output but would be approximate.     

@karolz-ms and I discussed and  think the better solution is to not duplicate the spec.args in annotations.  With a quick look I believe the arguments are stuffed into annotations for the dashboard to retrieve.  Perhaps a better approach would be to only add a key for the argument in annotations and look up the value when needed.

author: TanerSaydam
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Hi,

I’m using .NET Aspire 9.3 and created a solution where I run MSSQL, PostgreSQL, Redis, and RabbitMQ as containers inside Aspire.
I also added references from two projects to these containers, using wait-for so that the projects only start after the dependent containers are healthy.

The issue:
Sometimes, when I start the solution in Visual Studio (both with or without debugging), Aspire cannot start all the containers properly. Instead, one or more containers get stuck in the "unhealthy" state, and my projects wait indefinitely.

The strange thing is:

If I stop and restart the solution, or close and reopen, it usually works fine.

The issue occurs more frequently when I have multiple containers running together.

The issue seems related to startup timing/race conditions when multiple containers are being initialized.

It would be great if this could be investigated, since it affects developer workflow when using Aspire with multiple services.

Thanks! 🙏

author: mangeg
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Version 9.4.0 and 9.4.1 of Aspire.Hosting.AppHost causes container resources that are set to persistent container lifetime to be re-created on every start of the AppHost when the container has been annotated with `WithOtlpExporter()`.

I have compared all the environment variables set in the container and none of them changes between the starts from what I can see, but it still seems to be invalidated and recreated.

There was an earlier similar issue, https://github.com/dotnet/aspire/issues/6889, that was solved with saving the api-token in user secrets. But this seem to be something else. 

Running from VS, VS Code or dotnet CLI seems to be make no difference.

### Expected Behavior

Persistent containers with no configuration changes between runs should not be re-created. 

### Steps To Reproduce

- Create a new project using the `.NET Aspire Starter App` template
- Select Aspire 9.3
- Check `Use Redis for caching`

Once created:
- Change the Aspire AppHost SDK version to 9.4.1
- Change version of Aspire.Hosting.AppHost and Aspire.Hosting.Redis to 9.4.1
- Mark the Redis resource with `.WithLifetime(ContainerLifetime.Persistent)` and `.WithOtlpExporter()`

This will cause the Redis container to be re-created on each start of the AppHost from Visual Studio. Reverting the versions back to 9.3.1 solves the issue.

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

_No response_

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: davidfowl
nodes.body: cc @danegsta

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
I've figured out what was causing this and have a fix ready for the orchestrator.

It was specifically an issue with not evaluating service discovery tokens in the environment before calculating the config hash for persistence in one code path (something that gets added to the environment when enabling OTEL). This meant that the hash we were checking against the running container and the hash that we actually persisted with the container were being calculated with subtly different data.

title: Aspire 9.4.x causes persistent containers with WithOtlpExporter() to be re-created on each Aspire start

author: mateusrodrigues
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

Starting an Aspire AppHost that contains container services on a Linux system with Docker installed from the Snap Store will cause the container deployments to fail when no explicit container runtime is specified:
```
Container runtime 'docker' could not be found. See https://aka.ms/dotnet/aspire/containers for more details on supported container runtimes.
The error from the container runtime check was: docker command appears to be aliased to a different container runtime
```
The issue seems to be at the DCP level:
```
$ ~/.nuget/packages/aspire.hosting.orchestration.linux-x64/9.4.1/tools/dcp info | jq .
{
  "version": "0.15.20",
  "commitHash": "f3bbebcdc637a7af175106dc55591cb9e9c56ed2",
  "buildTimestamp": "2025-08-01T22:07:48Z",
  "containers": {
    "runtime": "docker",
    "hostName": "host.docker.internal",
    "installed": false,
    "running": false,
    "error": "docker command appears to be aliased to a different container runtime"
  }
}
```
The error message seems to hint at the fact that snap aliases do not link directly to the program's executable, but to a centralized snap entrypoint, e.g.:
```
$ ls -l /snap/bin/docker
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root 13 Aug 20 14:08 /snap/bin/docker -> /usr/bin/snap
```
However, the project runs as expected when explicitly specifying `ASPIRE_CONTAINER_RUNTIME=docker`. It seems that, at the DCP level, this causes a different behavior:
```
$ ~/.nuget/packages/aspire.hosting.orchestration.linux-x64/9.4.1/tools/dcp info --container-runtime docker | jq .
{
  "version": "0.15.20",
  "commitHash": "f3bbebcdc637a7af175106dc55591cb9e9c56ed2",
  "buildTimestamp": "2025-08-01T22:07:48Z",
  "containers": {
    "runtime": "docker",
    "hostName": "host.docker.internal",
    "installed": true,
    "running": true
  }
}
```

### Expected Behavior

The behavior of not explicitly specifying a container engine should be the same as specifying `ASPIRE_CONTAINER_RUNTIME=docker`.

### Steps To Reproduce

On a clean Ubuntu 24.04 box, run:

```
sudo addgroup --system docker
sudo adduser $USER docker
newgrp docker
sudo snap install docker
```
Install the .NET SDK from the Canonical backports PPA, as [documented](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/core/install/linux-ubuntu-install?tabs=dotnet9&pivots=os-linux-ubuntu-2404):
```
sudo add-apt-repository -y ppa:dotnet/backports
sudo apt install -y dotnet-sdk-9.0
```
With Docker and .NET installed, you can use [eShop](https://github.com/dotnet/eshop) as an example of the behavior described above.
```
git clone https://github.com/dotnet/eshop && cd eshop
sed -i 's/9.0.200/9.0.109/g' global.json
```
We need to replace the SDK version in the global.json file from `9.0.200` to `9.0.109`, because distros can only ship the [1xx SDK feature band](https://github.com/dotnet/source-build?tab=readme-ov-file#support), as that's the only source-buildable one so far.

Running the project displays the following warning:
```
dotnet run --project src/eShop.AppHost/eShop.AppHost.csproj

...
warn: Aspire.Hosting.Dcp.DcpHost[0]
      Container runtime 'docker' could not be found. See https://aka.ms/dotnet/aspire/containers for more details on supported container runtimes.
...
```
On the other hand, specifying the container runtime explicitly works:
```
ASPIRE_CONTAINER_RUNTIME=docker dotnet run --project src/eShop.AppHost/eShop.AppHost.csproj
```

### Exceptions (if any)

_No response_

### .NET Version info

```
$ dotnet --info
.NET SDK:
 Version:           9.0.109
 Commit:            a1e39f97e5
 Workload version:  9.0.100-manifests.d3740a48
 MSBuild version:   17.12.41+a1e39f97e

Runtime Environment:
 OS Name:     ubuntu
 OS Version:  24.04
 OS Platform: Linux
 RID:         ubuntu.24.04-x64
 Base Path:   /usr/lib/dotnet/sdk/9.0.109/

.NET workloads installed:
There are no installed workloads to display.
Configured to use loose manifests when installing new manifests.

Host:
  Version:      9.0.8
  Architecture: x64
  Commit:       a1e39f97e5

.NET SDKs installed:
  9.0.109 [/usr/lib/dotnet/sdk]

.NET runtimes installed:
  Microsoft.AspNetCore.App 9.0.8 [/usr/lib/dotnet/shared/Microsoft.AspNetCore.App]
  Microsoft.NETCore.App 9.0.8 [/usr/lib/dotnet/shared/Microsoft.NETCore.App]

Other architectures found:
  None

Environment variables:
  Not set

global.json file:
  /home/ubuntu/eshop/global.json

Learn more:
  https://aka.ms/dotnet/info

Download .NET:
  https://aka.ms/dotnet/download
```

### Anything else?

_No response_

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: The main issue here is likely that `docker` is being symlinked to `snap run` which is failing a check we do to differentiate the Docker CLI from a symlink to another runtime such as Podman to avoid accidentally using our Docker implementation when only Podman is actually . I'll update our logic to only consider a symlink to Podman as invalidating the Docker CLI.

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: @mateusrodrigues can you test this with a nightly build of Aspire? We've tweaked the logic such that you shouldn't need to force the specific runtime as a workaround.

title: Containers won't start with the Docker snap

author: tjwald
body:
### Is there an existing issue for this?

- [x] I have searched the existing issues

### Describe the bug

When using aspire to host locally the registry:3 image, I tried to push / pull images from the registry and the command times out, and the requests do not reach the registry itself (logs and traces show this).

Running the registry image directly without aspire works.
Also, if the registry is proxied using an executable then it also doesn't work.

### Expected Behavior

I should be able to push / pull images from the registry using docker cli from a registry hosted in aspire or any proxy executable I create for the registry.

### Steps To Reproduce

```csharp
builder.AddContainer(name, "registry", "3")
            .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 5000, targetPort: 5000, name: "http")
            .WithHttpHealthCheck("/v2/", endpointName: "http");
```

And then in terminal:

```sh
docker pull redis
docker tag redis localhost:5000/redis:latest
docker push ocalhost:5000/redis:latest
```

### Exceptions (if any)

Timeout on either connection or waiting for layer pull / push depending on the flavor of docker you are using (with or without containerd enabled)

### .NET Version info

.NET SDK:
 Version:           9.0.304
 Commit:            f12f5f689e
 Workload version:  9.0.300-manifests.6b700260
 MSBuild version:   17.14.16+5d8159c5f

### Anything else?

After investigation with @davidfowl and @danegsta they found the root cause and workaround for now.

### Root Cause:
Docker VM doesn't bind aspire ports / random ports from the host correctly in certain situations. 

Since the docker pull is happening in the Docker VM, the exposed post isn't available and the docker cli command timedout.

### Workaround:

Remove the proxy from your endpoints using:
```csharp
    .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 5000, targetPort: 5000, isProxied: false, name: "http")
```

And only containers can be used to proxy requests from the docker cli.

Full registry resource after fix:

```csharp
 builder.AddContainer(name, "registry", "3")
            // isProxied must be false for host machine docker client to be able to push images to it
            .WithHttpEndpoint(port: 5000, targetPort: 5000, name: "http", isProxied: false)
            .WithHttpHealthCheck("/v2/", endpointName: "http")
            .WithVolume("cortex-ai-registry", "/var/lib/registry")
            .WithOtlpExporter();
```

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body: The main issue here is that push/pull operations are done by the daemon, which is running inside a VM (or WSL distro) on Mac and Windows. There seems to be a Docker Desktop bug that's keeping ports from being exposed properly inside the VM when randomly assigned (everything works correctly when fixed ports are used). This results in the daemon being unable to actually push or pull to the registry container despite it being reachable from the host OS. A rough diagram of the issue:

nodes.author: danegsta
nodes.body:
I believe this existing issue in one of the Docker Desktop repos is the same thing that's happening here: https://github.com/docker/for-win/issues/14195

We'll raise this via some channels at Docker to try to get attention on it.

title: Docker pull from container registry image fails due to Proxy Usage / docker bug
